abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Food Crisis Response
            Project for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. The project
            included three components: i) block grants disbursements
            (US$7 million, 87.5 percent) would go towards building or
            rehabilitating small-scale irrigation projects in the most
            vulnerable provinces; ii) community facilitation and
            capacity building (US$600,000, 7.5 percent of total grant
            funding) would finance Facilitating Partner (FP) costs,
            including goods, services, and operations costs of NSP FPs;
            and iii) implementation and management support (US$400,000,
            5 percent of total grant costs), included both NSP II
            (National Solidarity Program) Management Support Consultant
            (MSC) and Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development
            (MRRD) management costs; and comprised incremental expenses
            incurred in project implementation and management. This
            included costs of services and operational expenses at the
            central, regional, and provincial levels. Some lessons
            learned included: the NSP experience illustrates the vital
            importance of strong and sustained commitment and vision on
            the part of key high level Government officials. NSP also
            illustrates how a national program reaching rural
            populations in remote parts of the country can help enhance
            the legitimacy of the government, as findings of the first
            follow up survey highlight this lesson. Decentralized task
            teams are essential especially in post-conflict/fragile
            state situations where continuous and intensive
            implementation assistance/supervision is needed. It
            facilitates greater support to communities, expedites
            sub-project preparation to completion cycle and strengthens
            project results monitoring on the ground.
